awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Assessing Mechanisms for Organosulfate Formation in Secondary Organic Aerosol
awd_abstract_narration:
A major goal of this project is to contribute to improving atmospheric chemical models that are critical to the mechanistic understanding of the processes that are relevant to air pollution and climate change.  This effort focuses on studying the production of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) related to the presence of organosulfates in the atmosphere. This Research in Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) project will support the education and training of undergraduate students and help prepare them for future careers in science.

The specific objectives of this research are to: (1) measure acid-catalyzed sulfate esterification rate constants for alcohol derivatives of targeted volatile organic compounds (VOCs); (2) investigate mechanistic details of the nucleophilic substitution of nitrate by sulfate reaction for nitrate derivatives of targeted VOCs; (3) investigate mechanistic details of sulfate radical addition to targeted olefinic VOCs reactions and identify sulfate radical formation mechanisms for aerosol proxy solutions irradiated by simulated solar irradiation; and (4) synthesize and characterize with Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, organonitrate reactants and potential organosulfate products relevant to the reactions studied.

This research will enable parameterization of the important mechanistic aspects of the various processes studied and allow for the determination of their potential importance under ambient atmosphere conditions.  The results will lead to more accurate modeling of organosulfate formation in SOA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Oberlin College-based research involved investigating potential chemical transformations on secondary organic aerosol (SOA), which are small airborne particles that play a role in air pollution, the energy balance of the atmosphere, and in the nucleation of clouds.  Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) methods were used to study bulk solutions that were similar to SOA in chemical composition.  In particular, the work showed that a certain class of organic molecules called organonitrates, which are present in the atmosphere due to emissions from vehicles and power plants, undergo some unexpected transformations on SOA.  These transformations help explain how organonitrates can lead to growth of SOA, and important, but still not totally understood process in the atmosphere.  The work also showed that organosulfates, which are present in the atmosphere due to power plant emissions, are probably not formed directly from alcohols.  This work should help to better predict the effects of SOA on the air pollution and climate change issues.

These findings were reported in 4 peer reviewed publications (with seven undergraduate students as coauthors) in the journals Environmental Science and Technology and the American Chemical Society Earth and Space Chemistry.  Seventeen undergraduate students were trained in the field of atmospheric chemistry as a direct consequence of their work on the project.
